name: Watermelon
description: Large, round fruit with a sweet, juicy flesh and a green rind. A quintessential summer treat.
nutrition: High in water content, vitamin C, vitamin A, and lycopene.  A great source of hydration.
uses: Eaten fresh, used in juices, salads, and smoothies.
cultivation: Vining plant that requires ample space and warm soil. Needs consistent watering throughout the season.
details: Flesh can be red, pink, yellow, or orange. Choose heavy melons that sound hollow when tapped.
instructions: Store whole watermelons at room temperature, cut pieces should be refrigerated.
water: Deep, consistent watering, especially during flowering and fruiting.
solutions: Proper spacing, avoid overhead watering, choose resistant varieties.
fertilizers: Balanced fertilizer at planting, side-dress with compost during the season.

name: Mango
description: Juicy, sweet fruit with a vibrant yellow-orange flesh. Known as the 'king of fruits' in many regions.
nutrition: Rich in vitamins A and C, fiber, and antioxidants. Contains unique compounds like mangiferin.
uses: Eaten fresh, used in juices, smoothies, salads, desserts, and preserves.
cultivation: Grows on large evergreen trees. Prefers warm climates with distinct dry periods.
details: Many varieties with different shapes, sizes, and flavors. Ripe mangoes are slightly soft and fragrant.
instructions: Purchase ripe mangoes or allow to ripen at room temperature if purchased firm.
water: Deep, infrequent watering for established trees.
solutions: Proper pruning for air circulation, fungicide applications if necessary, choose resistant varieties.
fertilizers: Balanced fertilizer for young trees, specialized mango fertilizer for mature trees.

name: Pineapple
description: Sweet, tangy fruit with a spiky skin and a crown of leaves. Contains bromelain, an enzyme with health benefits.
nutrition: Rich in vitamin C, manganese, and antioxidants. Contains bromelain, an enzyme with anti-inflammatory properties.
uses: Eaten fresh, used in juices, salads, desserts, and savory dishes.
cultivation: Grows on a low, herbaceous plant with sword-like leaves. Prefers warm, tropical climates.
details: Takes 1-2 years to fruit after planting. Ripe pineapples are fragrant and slightly soft.
instructions: Choose pineapples with healthy leaves and a firm base. Store at room temperature until ripe.
water: Regular watering during the growing season, reduce watering during the dormant period.
diseases: Pineapple fusarium wilt, pink disease, root rot.
solutions: Proper drainage, avoid overwatering, remove infected plants.
fertilizers: Balanced fertilizer during the growing season, avoid high-nitrogen fertilizers.

name: Strawberry
description: Small, sweet fruit with a bright red color and a juicy texture. Grows on low, spreading plants.
nutrition: High in vitamin C, manganese, and antioxidants. Contains ellagic acid, a compound with health benefits.
uses: Eaten fresh, used in desserts, salads, smoothies, and preserves.
cultivation: Grows on low, spreading plants. Prefers cool climates and well-draining soil.
details: Many varieties with different flavors, sizes, and shapes. Ripe strawberries are fragrant and bright red or pink.
instructions: Choose strawberries with bright color and fresh green leaves. Store in the refrigerator and consume quickly.
water: Regular watering, especially during flowering and fruiting.
diseases: Powdery mildew, botrytis fruit rot, verticillium wilt.
solutions: Proper spacing for air circulation, remove infected plants, choose resistant varieties.
fertilizers: Balanced fertilizer at planting, side-dress with compost during the season.

name: Banana
description: Sweet, creamy fruit with a distinctive shape and a yellow skin. Grows in clusters on tall, tropical plants.
nutrition: High in potassium, vitamin C, vitamin B6, and fiber. Contains unique compounds like dopamine and catechins.
uses: Eaten fresh, used in smoothies, desserts, and baked goods.
cultivation: Grows on tall, tropical plants. Prefers warm, humid climates with rich, well-draining soil.
details: Many varieties with different flavors, sizes, and colors. Ripe bananas are yellow with brown spots.
instructions: Choose bananas with yellow skin and brown spots. Store at room temperature until ripe.
water: Regular watering, especially during the growing season.
diseases: Panama disease, black sigatoka, banana bunchy top virus.
solutions: Proper sanitation, remove infected plants, choose resistant varieties.
fertilizers: Balanced fertilizer during the growing season, avoid high-nitrogen fertilizers.

name: Litchi (Lychee)
description: Small, round fruit with a rough, red skin and sweet, translucent-white flesh. Unique floral aroma.
nutrition: Good source of vitamin C, potassium, and copper. Contains polyphenols with antioxidant properties.
uses: Eaten fresh, used in desserts, juices, and cocktails.
cultivation: Grows on medium-sized evergreen trees. Thrives in subtropical climates with warm summers and cool winters.
details: The flesh surrounds a single, inedible seed. Ripe litchis have slightly soft skin and a sweet, fragrant smell.
instructions: Choose litchis with bright red skin and a slight give when pressed. Store at room temperature for a few days or refrigerate to extend shelf-life.
water: Regular, deep watering, especially during flowering and fruiting.
solutions: Proper sanitation, fungicide applications if necessary, pest control measures.

name: Papaya
description: Sweet, tropical fruit with a vibrant orange flesh and a green or yellow skin. Grows on tall, tropical plants.
nutrition: High in vitamin C, vitamin A, fiber, and antioxidants. Contains unique compounds like papain and carpaine.
uses: Eaten fresh, used in juices, smoothies, salads, and desserts.
cultivation: Grows on tall, tropical plants. Prefers warm, tropical climates with well-draining soil.
details: Many varieties with different flavors, sizes, and shapes. Ripe papayas are slightly soft and fragrant.
instructions: Choose papayas with firm skin and a slight give when pressed. Store at room temperature until ripe.
water: Regular watering, especially during the growing season.
diseases: Papaya ringspot virus, powdery mildew, anthracnose.
solutions: Proper sanitation, remove infected plants, choose resistant varieties.
fertilizers: Balanced fertilizer during the growing season, avoid high-nitrogen fertilizers.

name: Grapes
description: Sweet, juicy fruit with a variety of colors, flavors, and textures. Grows on woody vines known as grapevines.
nutrition: High in vitamins C and K, antioxidants, and resveratrol. Contains unique compounds like quercetin and catechins.
uses: Eaten fresh, used in juices, wines, jams, jellies, and desserts.
cultivation: Grows on woody vines known as grapevines. Prefers warm, temperate climates with well-draining soil.
details: Many    varieties with different flavors, colors, and uses. Ripe grapes are plump, firm, and sweet.
instructions: Choose grapes with plump, firm skin and a slight give when pressed. Store in the refrigerator and consume quickly.
water: Regular watering, especially during the growing season.
diseases: Powdery mildew, downy mildew, black rot.
solutions: Proper pruning for air circulation, fungicide applications if necessary, choose resistant varieties.
fertilizers: Balanced fertilizer during the growing season, avoid high-nitrogen fertilizers.

name: Blueberries
description: Sweet, tangy fruit with a deep blue color and a juicy texture. Grows on low, spreading plants known as blueberry bushes.
nutrition: High in vitamins C and K, fiber, and antioxidants. Contains unique compounds like anthocyanins and pterostilbene.
uses: Eaten fresh, used in desserts, smoothies, salads, and baked goods.
cultivation: Grows on low, spreading plants known as blueberry bushes. Prefers cool, acidic soil with good drainage.
details: Many varieties with different flavors, sizes, and colors. Ripe blueberries are plump, firm, and sweet.
instructions: Choose blueberries with a deep blue color and a slight white bloom. Store in the refrigerator and consume quickly.
water: Regular watering, especially during the growing season.
diseases: Mummy berry, anthracnose, phytophthora root rot.
solutions: Proper pruning for air circulation, remove infected plants, choose resistant varieties.
fertilizers: Acidic fertilizer for blueberries, avoid high-nitrogen fertilizers.
